awd_titl_txt: GP-IMPACT: Building a Comprehensive Geoscience Learning Experience
awd_abstract_narration:
Science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines play an increasingly important role in the economic prosperity and civic dialog of the United States. The geosciences make fundamental contributions that underpin a number of societally-relevant issues, including energy and natural resource development, sustainability, and mitigation of natural hazards. This project is addressing an anticipated shortfall in the number of geoscientists in the STEM workforce, as well as increasing STEM literacy in the populace through improving geoscience teacher training in Nebraska. Given the diverse populations available in this EPSCoR-eligible state, the project is especially focused on engaging, recruiting, and retaining students from a variety of ethnic and cultural backgrounds, in order to broaden participation of traditionally underrepresented students in STEM education and career paths.  Collaboration with smaller colleges in the region that do not have teacher-education programs in geoscience education is building capacity among the STEM teaching community in the state.

The University of Nebraska-Lincoln, in collaboration with Concordia University, Midland University, Peru State College, Creighton University, and the Lincoln Public Schools, among other institutions, is undertaking a suite of activities aimed at improving geoscience student recruitment, retention, and career readiness, including undergraduate students who are pursuing careers as geoscience teachers.  An immmersive 16-day inquiry-based geology field course for pre-service teachers from colleges that do not offer Earth Science endorsements provides authentic scientific experience and training.  A summer bridge program for students between high school and freshman year, which includes both a shorter field-based activity and on-campus activities, exposes students at critical transition points in their education pathway to career opportunities in the geosciences.  Targeted recruitment at public schools that have highly diverse student enrollments is supporting efforts to increase diversity in the geosciences and related STEM disciplines.  Incoming freshman are recruited into the Geoscience Learning Community, which provides community support, mentoring, and networking opportunities.  Students in the learning community are recruited and supported as "Learning Assistants" who help instruct introductory geoscience classes and engage as experts with other students; this activity has been adapted from a successful model established at the University of Colorado, Boulder.  Support for students to engage in research and internship projects and professional development is geared towared preparing students for a range of STEM careers, including teaching.  The project is also developing a toolkit of effective inquiry-based and discovery-learning teaching practices.

por.por_cntn:
This project was designed to address the shortfall of geoscientists in the STEM workforce and increase STEM literacy in the populace. It presents a comprehensive learning experience to strengthen the undergraduate program at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, and to improve geoscience teacher training in Nebraska using evidence-based and evidence-generating approaches and pedagogies. 

Intellectual Merit: This project:

(1) Offered a two-week immersive, inquiry-based geology field course to four cohorts of pre-service teachers from colleges in Nebraska that do not offer Earth Science endorsements to provide an authentic scientific experience. In this course, participants discover, observe, and interpret a variety of natural phenomena, focusing on Earth processes and geological history through inquiry-based instruction. Place-based learning is strongly employed, specifically, the course begins in Lincoln, Nebraska, visiting field locations along the Platte River, and then moving into the Rocky Mountains of Wyoming and through South Dakota before following the Niobrara River back to Lincoln.  Over the duration of the project 55 pre-service and in-service teachers participated in the field course with cohorts ranging from 7 to 17 participants. Participants demonstrated significant improvements in geoscience content knowledge, increases in self-efficacy in teaching earth science and an awareness of how to effectively implement the 3-dimensional aspects of the Next Generation Science Standards.

(2) Developed a summer Bridge program for students transitioning between high school and freshman year that includes a shorter 9-day inquiry-based field experience and campus-based opportunity to explore potential career paths in the geosciences. This project supported 46 students over 4 cohorts, many of whom went on to major in the geosciences. The bridge program led to an increased awareness of the geosciences and geoscience careers, increased geoscience content knowledge, increased number of geoscience majors and increase number of minorities in the geosciences (particularly women).

(3) Strengthened the undergraduate program in the Department of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences (EAS) at the University of Nebraska by supporting the development of a new student organization, SEAS (Students of Earth and Atmospheric Sciences), and offering monthly professional development opportunities to EAS majors that will allow them to become more successful in their career endeavors.

(4) Employed 15 students as learning assistants (LAs) to help instruct in introductory geoscience classes and engage as experts with other students. The objectives of this program were to increase understanding of geoscience concepts for both the LA and the students in the courses and to increase LA pedagogical knowledge.

Broader Impacts:  These experiences engage a primary group of learners in the K-12 community (pre-service educators and bridge program learning cohorts) who then convey the experience to students and peers at home high schools.  In addition, the authentic geoscience experience pre-service teachers gain, via the inquiry-based field course, is a tool-kit of effective teaching practices to be employed through their careers. Both of these are steps toward a STEM-literate society. Early exposure to field-based, discovery learning enhances the learning, perception, and problem-solving skills of the bridge program cohort of learners, providing them with authentic, career-relevant experience and insight necessary to perform at a high level in future geoscience coursework, and enter the STEM workforce well-prepared and engaged. At the college-level we developed institutional collaborations with six smaller colleges in our region that do not have teacher-education programs in geoscience education, providing opportunity for EAS staff to provide sustained geoscience exposure for their pre-service educators.

This program also made strides towards increasing diversity. The Bridge Program applicants were much more diverse than is currently in the field of geosciences. According to the Scientist and Engineers Statistical Data System (SESTAT), in 2019, women earned 37% of the earth and atmospheric science degrees, and only 11% of these degree holders were non-white. Started applications for the Bridge Program were much more diverse than the National Survey of College Graduates (NSCG). The students who attended were also more diverse than the NSCG, with 60% female, and 19% non-white. There was also greater representation in the Pre-service Field Course, with 62% of attendees being women.
